title: Mythology Words
description: Discover everyday English words that trace their origins back to Greek and Roman mythology!

questions.question: The word 'atlas' — meaning a book of maps — comes from which mythological figure?
options: Atlas, the Titan who held up the sky

questions.question: The word 'narcissism' derives from the myth of Narcissus. What happened to him?
options: He was turned into a tree
He fell in love with his own reflection

questions.question: Which planet and mythological god gave us the word 'mercurial,' meaning changeable or volatile?
The word 'odyssey,' meaning a long and eventful journey, comes from which Greek epic?
What mythological creature gives us the word 'chimera,' meaning a fanciful or impossible idea?
options: A fire-breathing creature with a lion's head, goat's body, and serpent's tail

questions.question: The word 'volcano' derives from Vulcan, the Roman god of what?
What does 'herculean' mean, derived from the hero Hercules?
The word 'panic' comes from Pan, the Greek god of what?
Which mythological figure inspired the word 'tantalize,' meaning to torment with something unattainable?
options: Tantalus, condemned to stand in water that receded when he tried to drink

questions.question: The word 'cereal' comes from Ceres, the Roman goddess of what?
What does 'Achilles' heel' refer to, based on the myth of Achilles?
options: A person's area of weakness or vulnerability

questions.question: The word 'muse' — meaning a source of inspiration — comes from the Muses. How many Muses were there in Greek mythology?
Which mythological box gives us a phrase meaning 'a source of many unforeseen troubles'?
The word 'echo' comes from a Greek nymph named Echo. What was her punishment?
options: She was trapped in a cave forever
She could only repeat what others said

questions.question: The word 'jovial,' meaning cheerful and good-humored, derives from Jove. Who was Jove?
options: Another name for Jupiter, king of the Roman gods
